BestSoFar.framework.core

Interface Workflow<I,O>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ChildOf<WorkflowContainer<I,O>>, Deletable, EventuallyImmutable, ParentOf<Element<?,?>>, Processor<I,O>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractWorkflow, WorkflowImpl

    public interface Workflow<I,O>
extends Processor<I,O>, ChildOf<WorkflowContainer<I,O>>, ParentOf<Element<?,?>>
    A workflow is a linear list of Element objects which sits in a WorkflowContainer.

    When a workflow processes an input, it has its Element objects process the data sequentially, for example: input -> Element1 -> data1 -> Element2 -> data2 -> ... -> LastElement -> output.

    The Workflow's input and output types are independent of its Elements, and are set at the workflow's construction.

    It is perfectly legal to have the wrong input/output types for the workflow, or to have neighbouring elements be type-incompatible. In these situations, the workflow will return false for isValid(), and should have a way to inform the user (eg. in the associated view there might be connectors between neighbouring elements which are red if incompatible).

    NB. For two elements to be type-compatible, the previous Element's output type must be castable to the next Element's input type.

    However, a Workflow MUST be type-compatible with its parent WorkflowContainer. This is done so that all code related to checking neighbouring elements' data types is in Workflow (and nowhere else). Otherwise all WorkflowContainers would have to worry about whether its Workflows match it's data types. If this assertion is ever broken, a ClassCastException is thrown.
